The system also includes electromechanical circuits for actuating control mechanisms like rudders, propellers, and sails. These components work together to ensure precise control and efficient energy recovery.  

• The SCADA system features a graphical user interface (GUI) that allows human operators to monitor and control the mobile structures remotely. The GUI displays real-time data such as position, velocity, heading, and weather conditions, enabling operators to make informed decisions. It also provides virtual reality representations of the vessel's attitude and weather patterns, aiding in navigation and energy optimization. Operators can manually override automated controls if necessary, ensuring flexibility in mission-critical situations.  

• The system employs advanced algorithms for path analysis, considering factors like wind speed, wave data, and vessel performance models to determine optimal routes for energy extraction or logistics. It uses semivariograms to map predictive

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a rolling body guide cage made from at least one ring element and multiple guide structures, produced through forming techniques. It also includes a method for manufacturing such a cage, aiming to reduce production costs and material waste.  
* The cage is composed of flat material ring segments joined in the circumferential direction, welded together before forming. This approach significantly reduces cutting waste, especially for cages with an internal diameter over 140 mm.  
* The flat material ring segments are welded along edge regions in engagement zones, with joint contours providing preliminary coupling. These contours are designed to minimize weld seam length while ensuring strong connections.  
* The ring segments are typically 120° segments punched from sheet metal, allowing efficient material use and requiring only three weld points per ring. This method is suitable for both radial and axial bearing cages, including groove and angular ball bearings.  
* The manufacturing method involves welding the ring segments, preferably using laser welding for high-strength, low-distortion joints. Alternatively, pressure welding or material accumulations like beads can be used to enhance weld quality.  
* The ring segments can be punched directly into a rotary plate, where they are sequentially joined and welded. This process allows overlapping punching and welding steps, improving efficiency and ensuring precise alignment.  
* Additional features include forming beads or depressions on the ring segments to improve weld quality and axial securing. These techniques ensure uniform material properties and mechanical strength across the cage.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The document describes methods and systems for using global satellite positioning (GPS) to obtain and store latitude and longitude coordinates of customer service locations, enabling service technicians to efficiently locate and navigate to these locations.  
* It also details a mapping system that generates driving directions for technicians traveling between multiple service locations, enhancing response times and customer service efficiency.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention describes a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, particularly magnetic fields, using two triaxial sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and a digital control unit. The system combines signals from the sensors to simulate a virtual sensor, enabling compensation of both homogeneous and inhomogeneous fields.  
* The control unit processes the sensor signals through a matrix-based algorithm to generate control signals for the coils, allowing for flexible and precise compensation. The system can handle gradient fields and adapt to changes in the interfering field structure without requiring physical reconfiguration.  
* When two compensation systems are used in close proximity, a feedback matrix is introduced to account for mutual interference, ensuring optimal performance. This approach avoids overcompensation or undercompensation and maintains effective field compensation in complex setups.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a method for investigating biological samples using CARS microscopy, which detects resonance signals generated by coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering.  
• CARS microscopy uses two lasers with different wavelengths to generate a CARS spectrum, enabling species-selective imaging without dyes or tags.  
• The method introduces resonance sites into samples via bioorthogonal reactions, enhancing detection of structures not inherently detectable by CARS microscopy.  
• Bioorthogonal reactions, such as Diels-Alder or Staudinger ligation, allow chemical tagging without interfering with biological processes.  
• The invention improves specificity and scattering cross-section in CARS microscopy, enabling better detection of target molecules in complex samples.  
• Resonance sites can be introduced by coupling intrinsic sample structures with reaction partners or generating them during the bioorthogonal reaction.  
• The method allows for reproducible counter-staining of non-resonant backgrounds, improving quantitative analysis in CARS microscopy.  
• Small molecules used in bioorthogonal reactions can penetrate deep into tissues, enabling three-dimensional imaging with CARS microscopy.  
• The invention is particularly useful for tagging biological samples like nerve tissue, combining vibrational spectroscopy with chemical tagging.  
• The method is depicted schematically in the figures, illustrating the coupling of intrinsic structures with reaction partners and the resulting resonance signal detection.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention provides a system for assessing segmentations in radiation therapy by comparing different segmentations, such as those from clinicians or autosegmentation software. It uses electronic files, typically in DICOM-RT format, to create volume models for comparison. The system identifies common, missing, and extra volume elements to evaluate segmentation quality.  
• The system converts segmentations into voxel-based volume models for precise comparison. It measures discrepancies by evaluating voxels in the union of the two models, identifying missing and extra elements. This voxel-based approach simplifies the comparison process using digital computer hardware.  
• A graphical interface displays cross-sectional images of the segmentations, highlighting common, missing, and extra volume elements with distinct colors. The display can overlay these elements on patient tissue images for better visualization. This feature aids in training clinicians and evaluating autosegmentation programs.  
• The system allows customization of metric methods to evaluate segmentation quality based on missing and extra volume elements. Metrics can include constant, linear, or exponential functions of distance from reference elements. Users can define and adjust these metrics to suit specific clinical needs.  
• Distance measures are used to weight the impact of missing and extra volume elements in the metric method. Errors closer to the segmentation surface are discounted, while distant errors are emphasized. This weighting approximates the clinical significance of segmentation discrepancies.  
• The system supports automatic matching of metric methods to specific anatomical structures based on text strings in the segmentation files. This feature ensures appropriate metrics are applied to different structures. Users can also manually adjust these mappings as needed.  
• A histogram display shows cumulative missing and extra volume elements as a function of distance ranges. This visualization helps identify systematic errors and distance-related trends in segmentation discrepancies. It provides additional insight into the quality of segmentations.  
• The system can be used for training clinicians, evaluating autosegmentation routines, and assessing new imaging technologies. It supports periodic quality assurance and product evaluation. The output can also inform decisions on updating treatment plans based on anatomical changes.  
• The invention includes a user-friendly interface for defining and adjusting metric methods. Users can input parameters for constant, linear, and exponential functions to create custom metrics. A graphical representation of the metric method is displayed to assist in development.  
• The system outputs quantitative evaluations of segmentation comparisons, including primary and secondary volumes, missing and extra volumes, and metric scores. A histogram table provides detailed distance-based analysis of discrepancies. Reports can be generated for further review and documentation.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to data processing systems, specifically focusing on improving the execution of floating point operations. Floating point format represents numbers using a fraction and an exponent, allowing a wider range of numerical manipulation. However, this format complicates addition and subtraction due to the need for fraction alignment and normalization.  
• Effective addition and subtraction operations are categorized based on operand signs, with effective subtraction being more complex. Effective subtraction involves aligning fractions, subtracting, normalizing, and rounding, which can be time-consuming. The invention aims to accelerate these operations by optimizing the subtraction process.  
• The invention divides effective subtraction into two procedures based on the absolute difference between exponent arguments (DELTA(E)). If DELTA(E) is greater than 1, normalization requires at most a one-bit shift, simplifying the process. If DELTA(E) is less than or equal to 1, fraction alignment and subtraction are streamlined, reducing the number of steps.  
• A subset of exponent argument signals (TDELTA(E)) is used to initiate fraction operations before the complete DELTA(E) is calculated. This subset difference allows early computation of fraction differences, reducing overall execution time. If the subset difference is incorrect, the correct result is one of the original operand fractions, which are readily available.  
• The invention introduces a technique where a 7-bit subset difference (T7DELTA(E)) is calculated to further accelerate operations. This subset difference determines the appropriate fraction shift and subtraction procedure. If the complete DELTA(E) invalidates the subset-based procedure, the correct result is either FRACTION A or FRACTION B, avoiding unnecessary calculations.  
• The apparatus includes subtraction units, detection logic, and selection logic to implement the accelerated procedures. The 7-bit and 6-bit subset differences are calculated first, enabling early initiation of fraction operations. The final fraction result is selected based on the complete DELTA(E) and the subset-based calculations.  
• The invention leverages the fact that shifting fractions by more than their bit length results in zero, simplifying the final result selection. When the subset difference indicates a large shift, the correct result is one of the original fractions. This approach minimizes computation time by avoiding unnecessary normalization and rounding steps.  
• The preferred embodiment uses a combination of subset differences and complete exponent differences to optimize the effective subtraction process. The subset differences allow early initiation of fraction operations, while the complete difference ensures accuracy. This dual approach significantly reduces the time required for floating point subtraction.  
• The invention provides a method and apparatus for accelerating

<summary>  
• The present invention addresses the persistent issue of mislabeling specimen vials in hospitals by introducing a method and system that uses unique machine-readable codes to track specimens. These codes are preapplied to patient ID bands, specimen containers, and staff badges, ensuring accurate identification and reducing errors. The system involves storing these codes in a relational database, verifying patient and order information, and generating signals to guide specimen collection. This approach eliminates the need for additional labels, reduces costs, and improves the reliability of specimen tracking.  
• The invention utilizes barcode scanners to read and verify patient, order, staff, and vial barcode numbers, ensuring all collected specimens are correctly matched to the patient and order. The system also includes checks for expired vials and monitors the time taken for specimen collection to ensure timely processing. By storing all relevant barcode numbers in a relational database, the system provides a complete and auditable record of each specimen collection event. This method enhances patient safety, reduces liability, and streamlines the specimen collection process in medical facilities.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention describes a voice-activated distance measuring device for golfers, incorporating GPS and voice recognition technology to provide audible distance and course information, with potential integration into headgear or clothing.  
• The device also features advanced functionalities like bone conductance sensors for improved voice recognition, Bluetooth connectivity for data transfer and communication, and the ability to record and analyze golf course data for strategic recommendations.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The present invention addresses challenges in semiconductor design verification, particularly for systems-on-chip (SOC) that integrate memory and logic circuits. It aims to eliminate false design rule check (DRC) errors by applying region-specific rules to logic and memory areas. The invention modifies standard logic rules to create customized rules for memory regions, ensuring accurate error detection. This approach avoids the inefficiencies of prior methods, which either flagged false errors or ignored memory-specific violations.  

* The invention introduces a system and method to categorize and apply distinct design rules for logic and memory regions within a chip layout. Customized memory rules are derived by analyzing violations in memory bit cells against standard logic rules and adjusting parameters accordingly. This ensures that memory regions are checked against relaxed rules, while logic regions adhere to stricter logic rules. The system can handle multiple memory types, such as BDSP SRAM, BLSP SRAM, DP SRAM, and ROM, each with its own set of rules.  

* A key feature is the ability to identify and separate logic and memory regions in mask pattern data using memory ID layers. This allows the design rule checker to apply the correct rules to each region, avoiding false errors and improving accuracy. Intermediate regions between logic and memory areas are checked using logic rules to ensure compatibility. The process is automated, reducing manual effort and speeding up the design verification cycle.  

* The invention is implemented using conventional computing systems and software routines, making it adaptable to existing workflows. It provides a more reliable and efficient DRC process by ensuring that only real errors are reported, eliminating the need for manual filtering. The method is applicable beyond semiconductors, including industries like LCD manufacturing, where different design rules apply to different regions. Overall, the invention enhances the accuracy and efficiency of design verification for complex integrated circuits.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• This invention involves waveguide holograms (WGHs) for controlled illumination of objects like holograms and spatial light modulators (SLMs). It builds on a prior patent application and uses thin substrate waveguides coupled to coherent light sources for high diffraction efficiency.  
• WGHs are compact and rugged, replacing complex lens systems and reducing alignment issues and reflection losses. They occupy significantly less space compared to conventional lens systems, making them ideal for demanding illumination tasks.  
• The invention addresses challenges like non-uniform illumination and alignment sensitivity. Non-uniformity is mitigated by exposing photographic emulsions to the beam or recording holograms non-uniformly to achieve uniform intensity.  
• WGHs can achieve high diffraction efficiencies, with undiffracted light trapped in the waveguide, minimizing stray light. This makes them suitable for applications requiring precise illumination, such as SLMs and display holograms.  
• The invention highlights the issue of illumination depletion, where light diffracted at one point is unavailable for later points. This is addressed by compensating for non-uniformity either before or after recording the hologram.  
• Two-sided diffraction in WGHs can be managed by absorbing light on one side, using mirrors, or employing off-axis illumination. These solutions ensure efficient use of the diffracted light and reduce noise in the system.  
• The invention describes two recording configurations for WGH gratings, one using a prism for steep incidence angles and another using a prism coupler for precise reconstruction. Both methods were tested using silver halide plates and thin glass waveguides.  
• Experiments demonstrated the flexibility of WGH illuminators, including white light illumination and coherent laser light for 3D holographic reconstruction. A diffuser was used to mix colors for uniform white light illumination.  
• The quality of reconstructed beams was analyzed, revealing slight depolarization and phase distortions. The invention emphasizes the need for precise recording configurations to achieve cleaner wavefronts and higher efficiency.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a method and apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors in dynamoelectric machines, such as induction motors, to measure resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew. These measurements help identify defects like porosity, impurities, or open circuits in the rotor's aluminum casting. The system is designed for non-destructive testing, ensuring economical and reliable quality control. It aims to provide automatic pass/fail determinations and detailed statistical analysis of rotor performance.  

• The test apparatus includes a test head with exciting windings to magnetize the rotor and voltage/skew pick-up coils to sense induced magnetic flux. The rotor is rotated within the test head, and the system measures voltage, current, and skew signals. A phase-locked loop synchronizes sampling of these signals, and a data processor calculates resistance, reactance, and skew values. The system also determines dissymmetry and skew dissymmetry to evaluate rotor uniformity.  

• The test head's structure resembles a stator core, with primary windings creating an alternating magnetic field and pick-up coils sensing rotor-induced voltages. The skew pick-up coil is positioned at the end of the core to measure flux build-up due to rotor skew. The system uses a sample-and-hold circuit to capture data, which is then digitized and processed. This design allows for precise measurement of rotor characteristics without requiring a stator core.  

• The apparatus includes a dual test fixture system with hydraulically driven retraction and rotation mechanisms for efficient testing. Each fixture is controlled by a common data acquisition and processing system, which automates the testing process. The system samples data over 40 cycles, calculating mean values for resistance, reactance, and skew. Statistical data is stored on a Winchester disk for further analysis and quality control.  

• The test sequence begins when an operator places a rotor on the test head and activates the start button. The rotor is retracted into the test position, and a motor rotates it at a rate of one revolution in four seconds. During rotation, the system samples voltage, current, and skew signals synchronously with the excitation current. The data is processed to determine rotor performance and pass/fail status.  

• The retraction and drive mechanism includes a spindle with a clutch system to securely hold the rotor during testing. In the extended position, the rotor can be easily mounted on the spindle, while in the retracted position, compressed o-rings grip the rotor tightly. This ensures stable rotation and accurate measurements. The hydraulic cylinder and motor assembly enable precise control

<summary>  
* The document describes a method for securing mobile devices by restricting third-party applications' access to native system resources. Managed libraries, validated through digital certificates, are granted access to native resources, while managed applications are denied direct access and must rely on these libraries.  
* A manager enforces security by verifying digital certificates and controlling access to native resources, ensuring that only trusted managed libraries can interact with the operating system. The runtime host, implemented in native code, facilitates access to native resources on behalf of the managed libraries.  
* The system includes a validation process for third-party applications, ensuring they are type-safe and free from malicious code before being packaged in digitally signed containers. These containers are distributed through an electronic marketplace, allowing secure execution on mobile devices while maintaining control over resource access.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention describes an improved identification card with an internal antenna and integrated circuit (IC) chip laminated between protective layers. The card uses non-rigid, shock-absorbing layers to protect electronic components from bending stresses, unlike prior art cards that rely on rigid materials. Rigid outer layers distribute external forces, safeguarding the IC chip and antenna.  
* The card comprises a core layer of silica-filled polyolefin, an antenna, and an IC chip electrically connected to the antenna. A bottom sheet of silica-filled polyolefin is attached to the core layer using adhesive, encasing the antenna and chip. Alkyd resin spids with an anti-binding agent are printed on the core layer to minimize damage to electronic components.  
* The core layer and bottom sheet are laminated between two rigid outer layers using adhesive. The outer layers provide structural support and protection, ensuring the card's durability. This design prevents cracking and delamination, common issues in prior art cards made from brittle materials like PVC.  
* The manufacturing process involves pre-shrinking the core layer to avoid shrinkage during printing and assembly. Alkyd resin spids and antennae are printed on the core layer, and IC chips are attached to the antennae. Recesses are cut in the adhesive layer to accommodate the IC chips, ensuring uniform card thickness.  
* The core layer and bottom sheet are bonded using a co-polyester-based adhesive, with additional adhesive applied to secure the IC chip. The lamination process involves controlled heat and pressure to ensure proper bonding without damaging the electronic components. This method simplifies production and reduces costs compared to mold-based processes.  
* Transparent polymer layers are affixed to the core and bottom layers, providing mechanical strength and protection. These layers can include image-receiving layers for printing variable indicia, such as personal information or security features. The polymer layers are typically made from materials like polyester or polycarbonate.  
* The card can include security features like UV-sensitive inks, optically variable inks, or fluorescent inks to prevent tampering or counterfeiting. A protective layer is applied over the image-receiving layer to prevent dye bleeding and enhance durability. This layer also adds additional security measures to the card.  
* An alternative embodiment uses inkjet printing for personalization, with an inkjet receiver coating applied to selective areas of the core layer. Personalized data is printed between the core layer and polymer layers, eliminating the need for an additional protective layer. This method simplifies the personalization process while maintaining card durability.

<summary>  
* The invention introduces a method for implementing a FIFO queue in a functional memory using a tree-shaped data structure. Updates are made via a "copy-on-write" approach, where only the path from the root to the update point is copied, reducing memory usage and improving efficiency. This method ensures logarithmic time and space complexity for updates relative to the queue's length.  
* The tree structure maintains balance and fill conditions, with leaf nodes at the same level and internal nodes mostly full except for edge nodes. Additions are directed to the first non-full node on the left edge, while deletions target the rightmost leaf node. This ensures efficient updates and maintains the queue's integrity.  
* A preferred embodiment includes a header node with three elements: pointers to the beginning, middle (tree structure), and end of the queue. Additions fill the end node first, while deletions remove entire leaf nodes from the tree, reducing the frequency of tree updates. This approach further optimizes memory usage and update speed.  
* The queue can be inverted in constant time and space using an inversion bit in the header node, enabling symmetrical operations like double-ended queue functionality. The structure supports both FIFO and LIFO principles, making it versatile for various applications. The invention also allows for flexible node sizes and separate storage of records and pointers.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention introduces methods to manufacture embedded EPROM devices using existing DRAM and standard logic technologies, enabling the integration of EPROM with DRAM or logic circuits on the same wafer. This reduces manufacturing costs and eliminates the need for high voltages, simplifying the design of supporting circuits.  
• The EPROM devices utilize DRAM storage capacitors as coupling capacitors, significantly increasing the gate coupling ratio and lowering operation voltages. This approach is particularly beneficial for DRAM redundancy circuits, replacing traditional fuses with reprogrammable EPROM cells for improved performance and reduced testing costs.  
• The invention also proposes stress effect programmable read-only memory (SEPROM) devices, which use electrical stress-induced changes in transistor properties to store data. SEPROM devices are compatible with any IC technology, making them ideal for embedded and security applications, though they may have limitations in reprogrammability and stress recovery.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention introduces a method for determining optimal feedback gains (P, I, and D) in feedback control systems, such as those used in automatic guidance vehicles (AGVs). The method involves executing feedback control with provisional gain values, detecting errors, calculating evaluation values, and iteratively adjusting gains to achieve optimal control characteristics. This approach eliminates the need for complex processes like the limit sensitivity method, which relies on detecting self-sustaining vibrations.  
* The evaluation values are calculated using specific functions: the ratio of the error curve length to time (LR) for the P gain, the integral of the error (Svv) for the I gain, and the integral of the absolute error (Asv) for the D gain. These functions help evaluate stability, accuracy, and response, respectively. The optimal gain values are determined when the evaluation values reach predefined ideal ranges or through function interpolation.  
* The method is applied to AGV running control, where the vehicle's lateral deviation and speed are feedback-controlled using PID control. The AGV runs along a predefined course, and gain values are adjusted iteratively for different course sections. Data from lateral deviation detectors and speed sensors are used to calculate evaluation values and refine the gains.  
* Two embodiments are described: one where gains are determined for each course section separately, and another where gains are adjusted continuously as the AGV runs the entire course. The second embodiment uses trigger signals at course boundaries to initiate gain adjustments, ensuring real-time optimization. Both methods aim to achieve stable, accurate, and responsive control without requiring complex multi-variable analysis.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to zoom lenses with increased relative aperture, high optical performance, and minimized physical size for use in cameras and video cameras.  
* The zoom lens comprises five lens units, including a positive first unit for focusing and a negative second unit for magnification variation.  
* The fourth lens unit converts diverging light into an almost parallel beam, while the fifth unit forms the image with specific lens arrangements.  
* Key design conditions are defined for the fourth and fifth lens units to ensure aberration correction and high optical performance.  
* The lens design minimizes spherical aberration, coma, and higher-order aberrations while maintaining a compact size.  
* The total length of the lens system is reduced to less than 10 times the diagonal of the effective picture frame (φ_A).  
* Numerical examples demonstrate the lens system's performance, with F-numbers ranging from 1.6 to 2.4 and zoom ratios up to 5.56.  
* The lens system achieves a total length of 9.13φ_A to 9.19φ_A, significantly shorter than prior designs.  
* The invention balances high relative aperture, zoom ratio, and image angle while maintaining compactness and optical quality.  
* The zoom lens is well-suited for photographic and video cameras, offering advanced performance in a reduced size.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a method and device for detecting elementary particles, enabling both individual particle detection and signal integration without prior knowledge of expected signal rates.  
* Discharging of charge pulses or signals from the detector is performed on the low-voltage side to improve signal/noise ratio and avoid leakage current interference.  
* A fast amplifier is used for amplifying individual signals, while a slow amplifier integrates signals, especially when signal rates exceed a threshold value.  
* Signal separation is achieved using capacitors or high-pass filters for low-rate signals and inductive elements or low-pass filters for high-rate signals.  
* The detector material, such as diamond, enables fast charge transport at room temperature, allowing detection over wide signal rate ranges.  
* Uncharged particles are detected by doping or coating the detector material with a converter material to generate electric pulses.  
* The device includes a support capacitor on the low-voltage side to maintain detector functionality at high ionization rates.  
* The invention is applicable in particle accelerators, reactor installations, and diagnostic devices like X-ray or CT scanners.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• This invention describes an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies used in friction clutches. The apparatus measures warpage and ensures the assembly meets specified tolerances without manual intervention.  
• The driven disc assembly is mounted on a splined hub and positioned between a stationary ring and a movable ring. A torque motor applies a predetermined torque to rotate the assembly while the movable ring adjusts to reduce frictional engagement.  
• The apparatus includes an electronic position sensor to measure the distance between the rings and an optical encoder to detect rotation of the driven disc assembly. These sensors provide precise data to determine if the assembly is within acceptable warpage limits.  
• A servo motor controls the movement of the movable ring via a ball screw shaft, allowing for rapid or gradual adjustments. The system automatically stops the motor when the driven disc assembly begins to rotate, indicating the release of frictional force.  
• The microprocessor compares the measured warpage to a standard value and determines if the assembly is good or defective. If the assembly is defective, the system alerts the operator and halts further movement until acknowledged.  
• The apparatus operates automatically, reducing the need for manual operations and improving efficiency in a production environment. It also provides external indications, such as visual alerts, to minimize operator error.  
• The system stores measurement data for statistical process control, enabling quality monitoring and analysis. This feature enhances the reliability and consistency of the manufacturing process.  
• The invention offers a faster, more accurate, and automated solution for spin checking driven disc assemblies compared to prior manual methods. It ensures precise measurements and reduces the risk of defective assemblies passing inspection.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The application claims priority to U.S. Provisional Patent Application Ser. No. 61/744,917, filed on Oct. 5, 2012, titled "Contourlet Appearance Model."  
* The invention was developed with government support under Army Research Office grants DAAD19-02-1-0389 and W911NF-09-1-0273, granting the government certain rights.  
* The invention relates to image processing, specifically face age-estimation and age-progression methods, systems, and software.  
* Face age-estimation is challenging due to variations in human faces and factors like gender, ethnicity, and environmental influences.  
* The invention uses a Contourlet Appearance Model (CAM) to extract robust facial features for age estimation.  
* CAM combines shape and texture models to handle noise and improve accuracy in age estimation.  
* The method involves training with landmarked face images and applying Support Vector Regression (SVR) to create aging functions.  
* A Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier distinguishes between youth and adult faces for accurate age estimation.  
* The system can be implemented on various computing devices, including smartphones, tablets, and servers.  
* The invention provides a cost-effective, efficient, and accurate solution for real-world applications like surveillance and age verification.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a matrix display device for merging two images with different definitions, such as a high-definition monochrome image and a lower-definition two-color image. The device uses a mosaic of pixel arrangements, where specific pixels are dedicated to each image, preserving the higher definition of the first image. The controller applies light intensity signals to the pixels, with some pixels receiving signals from the first image and others from the second image. Scaling means may be used to redimension the images if necessary.  

* The pixel arrangements can consist of four pixels, with three pixels dedicated to the first image and one to the second image, or two pixels for each image. The pixels dedicated to the first image emit a single color, while those for the second image emit a different color. The controller can apply attenuation functions to the first image's pixels when the second image's intensity exceeds a threshold, ensuring better visibility of the second image. This approach maintains the clarity of the first image while allowing the second image to be clearly visible.  

* The device can display images from different sensors, such as night vision, infrared, or X-ray sensors, merged with symbology or text. The controller can adjust the light intensity signals to enhance contrast, ensuring the second image remains visible even on lighter backgrounds. For example, the attenuation function reduces the intensity of the first image's pixels when the second image's intensity is high. This ensures that the second image's colors appear saturated and distinct.  

* The display device can use two controllers: one for the first image and another for the second image, allowing different resolutions and refresh rates for each image. This dual-controller setup minimizes power consumption and optimizes performance. The pixels dedicated to the second image can be associated with colored filters or emitters to produce the desired colors. This configuration is particularly useful for applications requiring low power consumption and high efficiency.  

* The invention also supports merging more than two images, with additional pixels dedicated to a third image, such as graphical or textual information. The controller can dynamically adjust the display based on the intensity of the second and third images, ensuring optimal visibility for all images. For example, when the second or third image is not visible, the corresponding pixels can display a combination of the first image's signals. This maximizes the resolution and clarity of the first image while maintaining the visibility of the other images.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention describes a mobile identification transmitter for keyless activation of a motor vehicle's security system, featuring a removable payment element for cashless transactions.  
* The transmitter has a housing with a receptacle for the payment element, which can be removed to block payment functions while maintaining vehicle security communication.  
* A closure mechanism seals the receptacle in the secure state, protecting sensitive components from moisture, dirt, and ensuring reliable functionality.  
* The payment element supports credit/debit card functions, communicates with payment systems, and can include microprocessors and storage for secure transactions.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The source document describes an imaging device, such as a xerographic machine, that enters a sleep mode to save energy when inactive. When the device wakes up, it warms up and performs imaging operations using toner. The toner's tribo-electro-static charge (tribo charge) is critical for image quality, but it decreases during long periods of inactivity, leading to inconsistent or darker images. To address this, the device uses a toner concentration (TC) sensor and a toner dispenser to adjust the toner supply and maintain optimal charge levels.  
* The document outlines methods and apparatus for charging toner based on periods of inactivity. An inactivity determining section monitors the device's usage patterns and predicts when the next usage will occur. The system calculates the decay of the tribo charge using a power law formula and adjusts the toner charge to a predetermined level before resuming operations. This ensures consistent image quality by pre-running the device to restore the toner's charge to normal operating levels.  
* The system includes components like a TC sensor, a controller, and a charging section to measure and adjust the toner charge. It uses adaptive algorithms to learn user patterns and predict future usage, storing this data for future reference. The methods can be implemented in software or hardware, depending on system requirements, and are adaptable to various imaging devices. The disclosed techniques aim to improve image quality and efficiency by maintaining optimal toner charge levels after periods of inactivity.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus that precisely controls bias currents for multiple magneto-resistive (MR) heads on a rotary drum. MR heads require bias currents to operate in a linear region and detect magnetic signals from recording media. The apparatus uses a single-channel rotary transformer to transmit control signals, enabling independent and precise regulation of bias currents for each MR head.  

• The apparatus includes a control signal generator on the stationary side and a decoder circuit on the rotary side to process control signals. These signals are transmitted via a rotary transformer and converted into D.C. voltages to control MR head bias currents. This structure simplifies the system and allows for high-precision control, even as the number of MR heads increases.  

• A regenerative integrated circuit on the rotary drum combines bias current supply and signal amplification for MR heads. It is controlled via digital signals (Data, Clock, and Chip Select) transmitted over a single control line. This setup ensures efficient and precise control of multiple MR heads without requiring additional rotary transformer channels.  

• The invention prioritizes the transmission of head switching and bias current control data to avoid signal loss or delays during head switching. This ensures that MR heads operate at their optimal points and prevents errors in signal reproduction. The control timing is carefully managed to handle the increased data volume from additional functions and integrated circuits.  

• The apparatus also supports bidirectional communication, allowing the stationary side to monitor the operating state of MR heads and detect faults. This feature enables quick responses to issues like thermal asperity noise or head malfunctions. The decoder and control signal generator are equipped to handle bidirectional data transmission efficiently.  

• The invention extends to recording/reproducing systems with both MR heads and recording heads mounted on the rotary drum. Recording heads and MR heads are arranged at 90° intervals, enabling simultaneous recording and reproduction. The recording currents for recording heads are also independently controlled, optimizing performance and reducing heat generation.  

• The rotary transformer design minimizes cross-talk between power, control, recorded data, and reproduced signal channels. Short rings are inserted into transformer slots to reduce interference. The system can be implemented with planar or coaxial cylindrical transformers, offering flexibility in design and reducing the size of the rotary drum.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention improves locating and tracing concealed conductive objects like pipes or cables, especially when adjacent objects are present.  
• Prior art methods use passive techniques (e.g., gradiometers) or active techniques (e.g., inducing currents) but struggle with interference from nearby objects.  
• The invention introduces a system with a transmitter and receiver, using distinguishable alternating currents to trace adjacent objects accurately.  
• The transmitter employs two antennae to induce separate currents in adjacent objects, while the receiver senses magnetic fields from both currents.  
• Output signals from the receiver produce distinct nulls over each object, simplifying tracing even when objects are close together.  
• The system uses techniques like different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, or pulse rates to distinguish currents in adjacent objects.  
• The receiver processes combined signals to produce beat frequencies, enabling detection of both objects simultaneously.  
• Optimal transmitter positioning enhances signal strength and reduces interference between adjacent objects.  
• The invention is particularly effective when the horizontal separation between objects is less than 1.5 times their depth.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention describes an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to enable hands-free automatic answering and communication.  
• It includes a timer to control call duration and a bypass switch to override the timer for extended conversations.  
• Two embodiments are disclosed: one using an optocoupler circuit and another using a neon lamp and photocell for electromechanical coupling.  
• The system is modular, portable, and designed for easy installation, making it suitable for various environments like hospitals or workplaces.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to optical fiber communications, focusing on undersea networks with trunk and branch ring topologies to enhance survivability against cable cuts. It addresses the need for multipoint-to-multipoint connectivity and robust systems that maintain connections even during faults. The use of ring topologies and trunk-branch structures ensures network resilience, as single cuts isolate only affected branches while the trunk remains operational. This design reduces the impact of common undersea cable failures.  

• The system replaces traditional undersea optical repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers powered by energy transmitted through branch cables. This reduces costs and complexity while maintaining signal amplification. The trunk is configured in a ring topology with hubs and branching units, allowing for signal routing and amplification without additional repeaters. Optical energy is transmitted at a wavelength distinct from signal wavelengths to power the amplifiers.  

• The network includes hubs, branching units, and cable stations, with optical amplifiers embedded in the trunk or branch cables. Hubs act as regional switching offices, aggregating and routing traffic onto the trunk, while cable stations serve as local access points. The system uses wavelength-division-multiplexing (WDM) for signal transmission, with wavelengths typically in the 1500-1600 nm range. Optical amplifiers, such as erbium-doped fiber amplifiers, are powered by light sources like cascaded Raman lasers.  

• Branch assemblies connect cable stations to the trunk via branch fiber optic cables, which also transmit optical energy for amplification. These cables are susceptible to damage in shallow waters but isolate only the affected station if cut. Branching units allow for tunable add/drop of signal wavelengths, enabling network reconfiguration. The system ensures that branch cuts do not compromise the integrity of the trunk ring.  

• The invention leverages passive repeaterless technology, using branch cables to transmit both communication signals and energy for amplification. This eliminates the need for additional fiber runs and reduces capital and maintenance costs. The maximum distance between light sources and amplifiers is currently limited to about 100 km due to fiber attenuation. However, advancements in fiber technology and light sources are expected to extend this range.  

• The system is adaptable for both undersea and terrestrial applications and supports various multiplexing methods beyond WDM. It offers advantages such as full connectivity during trunk cuts, isolation of branch failures, and compliance with sovereignty concerns in undersea networks. The design also allows for reconfigurable wavelength routing and reduces operational costs. Overall, the invention provides a cost-effective, resilient, and

<summary>  
* The invention introduces a two-part cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices, designed to hide unsightly and potentially hazardous fasteners. The first part, an attachment plate, is mounted to the wiring device using screws, while the second part, the cover plate, latches onto the attachment plate without visible fasteners. The cover plate features saw-tooth racks that engage latching pawls on the attachment plate, allowing for independent adjustment to accommodate uneven walls. A small tool can be inserted through a slot to separate the cover plate from the attachment plate when needed.  

* The cover plate device is versatile and can be used with single or multiple ganged boxes, accommodating various wiring devices like switches and receptacles. The number of latching pawls, racks, and tabs varies depending on the number of wiring devices covered, ensuring proper alignment and secure attachment. For even numbers of wiring devices, there are odd numbers of pawls and racks, while odd numbers of wiring devices result in even numbers of pawls and racks. This design ensures the cover plate can adapt to wall irregularities, especially in larger installations.  

* The invention provides a quick and easy installation process using simple tools and standard fasteners, eliminating the need for exposed screws. The cover plate's design ensures a finished look without visible hardware, enhancing safety and aesthetics. The ability to independently engage pawls and racks allows the cover plate to conform to uneven wall surfaces, making it suitable for various wall types. Overall, the invention improves the installation and appearance of wall-mounted electrical wiring devices while addressing prior art limitations.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a collapsible light-shielding device for screens, designed to reduce reflections and improve image clarity.  
* It consists of concentrically nested annular strips that slide over each other between pushed-in and pushed-out positions.  
* The strips have a decreasing wall thickness in the axial direction, allowing adjustable angular positioning for viewing from different angles.  
* Hook or locking elements on the strips ensure reliable folding and prevent separation during use.  
* An adapter member with a compressible recess enables attachment to monitors with flat or curved fronts.  
* The device is compact, easy to install, and can be produced inexpensively using injection-moulding or bent plate material.  
* The invention provides a versatile, space-efficient solution for light shielding on various types of screens.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention introduces a system that automatically detects a speaker's speech rate and compares it to a listener's comprehension threshold, notifying the speaker to slow down if the rate exceeds the threshold. This system can be implemented in wearable devices or integrated into communication tools, using sensory mechanisms like vibrations or visual alerts.  
* The system considers factors such as the listener's language proficiency, speech clarity, and network quality to adjust the speaking rate threshold. It also offers the option to switch to a shared alternative language if both speaker and listener are proficient in it, enhancing overall comprehension.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention describes a device for optically recording rapid processes using a TV camera, enabling higher picture sequence frequencies with simple modifications. It achieves this by deviating and suppressing the scanning beam to run cyclically over N lines of a picture plane.  
• A cyclic line counter counts line pulses and generates an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, where N/p is an integer significantly greater than 1. This pulse controls beam suppression and vertical deviation via a sawtooth generator synchronized with the counter.  
• The device allows flexible adjustment of time resolution by programming the counter to different values of p, such as 8, 12, or 24, which are integer dividers of 312. This enables optimal balance between time and spatial resolution based on the process being recorded.  
• By reducing the number of scanned lines per picture, the device achieves high picture repeat frequencies, such as 2000 sec^-1 for p=8, while maintaining high horizontal resolution. Vertical resolution is sacrificed but can be optimized by aligning the process axis with the line direction.  
• The video signals can be digitized and stored for computer-assisted analysis, allowing synthetic picture reconstruction through interpolation or repetition of scanned lines. This eliminates the need for expensive film cameras and enables immediate digital evaluation.  
• The device is versatile and can be adapted for recording IR, UV, or X-ray images, making it suitable for various laboratory and industrial applications requiring rapid process analysis. It also supports staggered scanning cycles to fill gaps in vertical resolution for digital evaluation.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The present invention introduces a method for integrating voice and multimedia services into a single communication session, known as a blended call. This approach allows legacy telephony equipment to support multimedia capabilities without requiring costly hardware replacements. A multimedia server, equipped with "blender" software, manages the blended call by handling both voice and multimedia components. The blender ensures seamless integration by controlling signaling paths and preventing infinite loops between the telephony server and the multimedia server.  

• The invention addresses the limitations of existing systems by enabling multimedia services on legacy networks, preserving the functionality of older equipment. It avoids the high costs and service disruptions associated with replacing existing infrastructure. The blender software facilitates parallel voice and multimedia sessions, ensuring compatibility with current telephony protocols. This solution is particularly suited for SIP-based networks, where it leverages SIP-T messages for call setup and teardown.  

• Incoming calls are processed by checking if the recipient supports blended services through a database query. If blended services are supported, the call is routed to the blender, which initiates separate voice and multimedia components. The voice component is handled by the telephony server, while the multimedia component is managed by the multimedia server. The blender ensures that the telephony server does not redirect the call back, preventing infinite loops.  

• Outgoing calls from blended-capable clients are similarly processed, with the telephony server verifying blended capabilities before routing the call to the blender. The blender initiates parallel voice and multimedia sessions, maintaining control over the signaling paths. The multimedia server handles call disposition, such as call forwarding or voice mail, while the telephony server manages the voice component. This approach ensures that multimedia services are readily available when needed.  

• The invention supports various network configurations, including SIP-enabled environments, and integrates with Intelligent Network (IN) systems for advanced call handling. It allows mid-call activation of multimedia features by leveraging the multimedia server's access to signaling paths. The blender software can be implemented as software or hardware, providing flexibility in deployment. This solution is backward-compatible, ensuring that existing services remain functional during the transition to blended capabilities.  

• The communication environment includes telephony servers, multimedia servers, and client devices such as telephones and computers. The telephony servers handle voice calls, while the multimedia servers manage multimedia sessions, with the blender coordinating between them. Clients may have feature-limited user agents, such as SIP terminals, which are supported by the blended call framework. The system is designed to work with various connection types, including DSL, cable, and wireless networks.

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a content synchronization framework for connected devices, enabling dynamic attribute-based synchronization and file bundling.  
* It addresses limitations in existing methods, such as lack of priority-based synchronization and inability to resume interrupted downloads.  
* The framework uses a central reference point to process client requests, prioritize downloads, and construct response bundles.  
* Clients send dynamic attributes (e.g., device type, location) to the central reference point, which compiles relevant file bundles.  
* Bundles include file descriptions, download priorities, and actions (e.g., decompression) to guide client processing.  
* Clients create delta lists to identify outdated or missing files and download them in priority order.  
* The system supports resumption of failed downloads at the bundle level, ensuring efficient synchronization.  
* External partner servers can provide additional context or content to enhance synchronization responses.  
* The framework is scalable, supports multiple languages, and optimizes bandwidth usage through data compression.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention provides a system and method for facilitating anonymous communication between a finder of a lost object and its owner. It uses unique IDs and virtual locales (e.g., websites) to enable secure and timely communication without revealing personal contact details. This approach overcomes privacy and currency issues associated with traditional tagging methods.  
* Owners register unique IDs and contact information in a centralized database, associating these IDs with specific objects. Tags containing the ID and a reference to a virtual locale are attached to objects, enabling finders to access the system. This ensures that contact information remains current and secure.  
* The system includes a user interface for owners to manage their registered tags, update contact information, and view open cases. Owners can log in, add or edit tags, and communicate with finders through anonymous email addresses. This process ensures privacy and control over communication.  
* Finders access the system via the virtual locale referenced on the tag and can log in or register as new users. They can search for an ID, send one-way messages to owners, or open a case for ongoing communication. The system generates anonymous email addresses to protect both parties' identities.  
* The system supports multiple communication methods, including email and instant messaging, to ensure timely delivery of messages. Owners can receive alerts through various platforms, such as AOL, Yahoo, or SMS, based on their registered preferences. This flexibility enhances the likelihood of successful communication.  
* A server periodically checks for incoming emails and processes them by verifying anonymized addresses and matching them to open cases. If valid, the system forwards the message to the appropriate party while maintaining anonymity. Invalid or mismatched emails trigger automated responses to inform the sender.  
* The system also handles instant messages by validating the sender's identity and forwarding messages to the owner's registered contact methods. It ensures that messages are delivered across multiple platforms, such as AOL, MSN, or Yahoo Messenger. This feature enhances the system's responsiveness and usability.  
* The invention is adaptable to various programming languages, operating systems, and database systems, making it versatile and scalable. Open-source tools and modules, such as Perl and MySQL, can be used to implement the system. This flexibility allows for customization and integration with existing technologies.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to electron multipliers, specifically foil electron multipliers, which use thin foils to amplify electrons in transmission stages. These multipliers are designed for applications like photomultipliers and particle detectors, offering advantages such as higher gain per stage and simpler fabrication compared to traditional designs. The foils are arranged in series within an evacuated enclosure, with an electric field accelerating electrons through each stage. This design enables efficient electron multiplication and position-sensitive detection of incident particles.  

* Conventional electron multipliers include discrete dynode multipliers and continuous electron multipliers like microchannel plates (MCPs). Discrete dynode multipliers use a series of dynodes to amplify electrons, while MCPs use high-resistivity glass channels. Both types rely on secondary electron emission to achieve gain, but they have limitations in fabrication complexity, cost, and ion feedback. The foil electron multiplier addresses these limitations by using thin foils to create a more efficient and robust design.  

* The foil electron multiplier operates by accelerating incident particles and secondary electrons through a series of thin foils, each biased to create an electric field. Secondary electrons are generated at the rear surface of each foil and continue to the next stage, creating an electron avalanche. The gain of the multiplier depends on factors like foil thickness, applied voltage, and secondary electron yield. This design allows for higher gain per stage and fewer stages compared to conventional multipliers.  

* Key advantages of the foil electron multiplier include higher gain efficiency, simpler fabrication, lower cost, and the ability to cover larger areas. The fabrication process involves evaporating foil material onto a glass slide and transferring it to a support grid, which is less complex than MCP fabrication. Additionally, the design intrinsically rejects ion feedback, as ions generated at one stage cannot propagate far enough to create significant secondary pulses. These features make the foil electron multiplier suitable for applications like night vision devices and flat screens.  

* The foil electron multiplier's gain is modeled by equations that account for electron transmission, secondary electron yield, and the number of stages. The gain increases with the number of stages and the applied voltage per stage, reaching a maximum at an optimal voltage. The design allows for position-sensitive detection, enabling applications that require spatial resolution. The multiplier's performance is demonstrated through experiments with ion beams, showing higher gain efficiency than conventional multipliers.  

* Foil dimensions and materials are critical to the multiplier's performance, with carbon being the preferred material due to its thinness and uniformity. Foil thickness ranges from 0.2 to 2 μg/cm²,

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a 3-D viewing system called the 3-D Phenomenoscope, which allows viewers to experience a 3-dimensional effect from ordinary 2D motion pictures. It utilizes the Pulfrich effect, where lateral motion in the film creates a depth illusion when viewed through specially controlled lenses.  
* The system uses glasses with individually controllable lenses that can darken or clear based on real-time processing of the motion picture. A digital sensor captures the film frames, and a processor analyzes them to detect lateral motion and synchronize lens states accordingly.  
* The 3-D Phenomenoscope works with any motion picture format, including film, digital, TV, or DVD, without requiring modifications to the original content. It is designed to be lightweight, battery-powered, and free of wired or wireless connections for ease of use.  
* The lenses can take three states: both clear, left clear/right dark, or left dark/right clear, depending on the direction of lateral motion detected. This synchronization enhances the 3D effect for scenes with sustained lateral movement, such as chase sequences.  
* The system overcomes limitations of traditional 3D technologies, such as the need for special cameras, dual-image filming, or complex projection equipment. It also eliminates viewer discomfort caused by flicker or improper synchronization in other 3D systems.  
* The invention leverages technologies like liquid crystal lenses, digital photo sensors, and miniaturized processors to achieve real-time image processing and lens control. These components enable the system to detect motion and adjust lens states dynamically.  
* The 3-D Phenomenoscope can be used with older films, allowing classic movies to be viewed with a 3D effect without altering the original content. This makes it a versatile tool for enhancing viewer experience across a wide range of media.  
* The system includes algorithms to detect lateral motion and determine synchronization events, ensuring the lenses are adjusted to match the direction of movement. These algorithms can be adapted for more complex motion detection in future embodiments.  
* The invention aims to make 3D viewing more accessible and comfortable, reducing barriers like production costs, special equipment, and viewer discomfort. It represents a significant advancement in bringing 3D effects to mainstream motion picture viewing.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention introduces a method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using mechanical pressure instead of traditional wafer saws. This approach involves forming trenches along scribe lines on the wafer and applying pressure to create clean breaks, singulating individual die. The process addresses issues like slow cutting speeds, maintenance requirements, and chipping in thinner wafers. The apparatus includes a pad, a positioning member, and a pressure mechanism to facilitate the singulation process.  

• The method begins with fabricating circuitry on the wafer, applying a photo resist layer, and patterning it to expose scribe lines. Trenches are then etched along these lines, with depths varying based on wafer thickness and application needs. An optional back-grinding step can further reduce wafer thickness, and adhesive tape is applied to the back surface. Pressure is applied to the back surface, causing the wafer to break along the trenches and singulate the die.  

• The invention supports various wafer sizes and die types, including memory, logic, and analog chips. Trenches can be formed using etching or partial cutting with a wafer saw, and they can be created on either the active or non-active surface of the wafer. The process is adaptable to future advancements in wafer thickness and handling technology. The invention emphasizes flexibility and efficiency, aiming to improve yield and reduce production time in semiconductor manufacturing.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to a field emission display (FED) device with a protection structure to prevent damage from ionized gases. The structure includes reduction plates or electrodes that deflect ionized gases away from field emission elements, preventing electrical surges and burnout.  
* FED devices overcome limitations of liquid crystal displays (LCDs) by using phosphors to produce light, eliminating the need for backlights and reducing power consumption. However, ionized gases in FEDs can damage field emission elements by causing current surges.  
* The protection structure uses negatively charged reduction plates to attract and neutralize positive ions, preventing them from reaching the cathode. This prolongs the lifespan of the field emission elements and improves device reliability.  
* In one embodiment, elongated reduction plates are arranged parallel to rows of field emission elements. In another, reduction plates are arranged in a meshwork or net-shaped pattern among the elements.  
* The reduction plates are fabricated using photolithography and etching techniques, ensuring precise placement and integration with the cathode structure. This design enhances the efficiency and durability of FED devices.  
</summary>

<summary>  
* The invention relates to an image sensor with multiple imaging planes, addressing limitations in prior art CCD sensors that cannot simultaneously image opposing surfaces. It introduces a sensor capable of recording information through edge surfaces, overcoming the need for multiple sensors.  
* The image sensor comprises a semiconductor substrate with major and edge surfaces, where one edge is light-receptive. It includes image sensor elements with charge collection and transfer means, enabling charge carriers generated by light to be guided toward the collection means.  
* In one embodiment, the sensor has an elongated P-type substrate with imaging planes on the top and two edge surfaces. It features three columns of image sensor elements, each with a buried-channel CCD and an image sensing region, including a photodiode for the top imaging plane.  
* P+ layers are formed between the edge surfaces and adjacent image sensor elements, creating a barrier to electron movement. This guides charge carriers generated at the edges toward the middle of the substrate, where they diffuse laterally toward the CCDs.  
* The sensor allows imaging in multiple planes, enabling applications like simultaneous imaging of opposing surfaces or surface imaging of passageways. It uses doped layers to create a waveguide-like structure, compatible with existing image sensor fabrication techniques.  
* A second embodiment extends the N-type regions of the CCDs to the edges, improving charge collection and reducing crosstalk. This modification increases the lateral extent of the depletion region, enhancing performance.  
* The sensor can be mounted with bond pads shifted to the ends to avoid interference, and opaque coatings can prevent stray light absorption. It is suitable for various applications, including color imaging with filters for red, green, and blue planes.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention relates to home networks with power management systems, addressing the issue of high energy consumption by network devices. A typical network appliance consumes significant power even when not performing its primary functions, leading to unnecessary costs. Energy Star guidelines require devices to reduce power consumption when idle, but this is challenging for network master nodes performing administrative tasks.  
• The invention proposes methods to transfer network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device to minimize power consumption. When a master device enters a power-saving mode, it transfers administrative functions to a slave device, ensuring network continuity. This transfer allows the master device to reduce power usage while maintaining network functionality.  
• The system includes devices like video servers, audio servers, and entertainment systems connected via a network medium. Devices can serve as master or slave nodes, with master nodes handling administrative tasks like beacon transmission and bandwidth management. Slave nodes perform nominal functions and can be promoted to master roles under specific conditions.  
• A master device, when instructed to enter power-saving mode, checks for network traffic and sends a transfer request to slave devices. If no traffic is found, the master device enters power-saving mode directly. If traffic exists, the master device waits for responses from slave devices to determine the best candidate for the transfer.  
• The master device selects a slave device based on criteria like visibility, intelligence, or functional capabilities. Visibility refers to how many devices a slave can communicate with, while intelligence and capabilities relate to processing power and bandwidth. The master device may also consider user preferences when selecting a new master.  
• Once a slave device is selected, the master device transfers administrative functions to it, enabling the slave to become the new master. The original master device then enters power-saving mode, reducing overall network energy consumption. This process ensures that the network remains operational and efficiently managed.  
• Slave devices, upon receiving a transfer request, check if they are in power-saving mode before responding. If active, they send a request reply to the master device, indicating their willingness to accept administrative functions. If selected, the slave device receives the transferred functions and becomes the new master.  
• If no master device is active, any device on the network can self-promote to the master role by checking for beacons. If no beacons are detected, the device assumes the master role and performs administrative tasks. This ensures network continuity even if the original master fails or goes offline.  
• The invention provides a flexible and efficient method for managing power consumption in home networks while maintaining network performance. By

<summary>  
• The invention relates to antenna arrays for measuring the direction of electromagnetic radiation, particularly at low elevation angles where ground reflections cause interference. It builds on prior art, such as UK Patent No. 1449196, which used an equi-spaced triplet to measure elevation angles independent of ground reflection coefficients. This invention extends the concept by optimizing angle measurements using multiple triplets.  
• The prior art used a single equi-spaced triplet to derive signals A+C and B, which are functions of elevation angle and ground reflection coefficient. The quotient of these signals eliminates dependence on factors like antenna pattern and transmitted power. This allows for accurate elevation angle measurements, especially when the signal strength is near its maximum.  
• At low elevation angles, the ground reflection coefficient approximates -1, simplifying the signal function S. The height h of the triplet can be chosen to maximize S, ensuring accurate measurements when S changes slowly. The spacing d between elements also affects sensitivity, with d = λ/2 providing a range of values from 1 to -1 over 90 degrees.  
• The invention introduces an antenna array with at least four antennae forming two or more equi-spaced triplets perpendicular to a ground plane. Each triplet has a unique spacing d and height h, optimized for specific elevation angles. This arrangement reduces ambiguity in angle measurements, especially at low elevations.  
• The array operates using radio interferometric techniques, with each triplet producing signals A+C and B. These signals are processed to derive a quotient that depends only on elevation angle, not on ground reflection coefficients. The system can operate in both receive and transmit modes, with coherent carriers required within each triplet.  
• A practical embodiment uses three triplets with seven antenna elements, optimized for secondary surveillance radar at a 30 cm wavelength. The design aims for unambiguous angle measurements up to 7 degrees, with high accuracy and resolution. The spacing d and height h are chosen to maximize signal strength at specific elevation angles.  
• The three triplets are optimized for different elevation ranges: one for 1 and 3 degrees, another for 2 degrees, and a third for 5 degrees. Measurements from all triplets are compared to determine the most accurate result, with a weighted average providing the final elevation angle. This approach ensures high measurement integrity and reliability.  
• Typical values for d and h are provided, with the highest antenna element placed about 7 meters above the ground. The relationship h = 2d ensures that common values of sin θ satisfy the

<summary>  
• The invention relates to high-intensity, thermal, efficient incandescent lamps, particularly subminiature lamps, and a system for creating a liquid-tight seal. Traditional subminiature lamps use adhesives to secure glass envelopes within metal sleeves, but these adhesives degrade due to thermal cycling, cleaning, and moisture infiltration. These factors lead to premature lamp failure and safety hazards, such as burns from heat conduction.  
• Conventional subminiature lamps face issues like adhesive breakdown from thermal cycling, which can reach temperatures up to 300°C. The mismatch in thermal expansion between glass and metal causes destructive shear forces, further degrading the adhesive. Additionally, cleaning and sterilization processes in medical environments accelerate adhesive degradation and moisture infiltration, leading to corrosion and failure.  
• Proposed solutions, such as internal O-rings, have proven ineffective due to manufacturing challenges and limited sealing capabilities. External O-rings only prevent liquid entry from the socket end, leaving other areas vulnerable. The invention aims to address these issues by providing a longer-lasting, safer, and more reliable lamp assembly.  
• The invention introduces a subminiature lamp assembly using a high-temperature polymer, such as fluoroelastomer, to create a liquid-tight seal around the glass envelope. This polymer provides extended axial sealing, heat resistance, and chemical resistance while simplifying handling. The polymer surrounds the glass envelope and is supported by a metal base, eliminating the need for adhesives.  
• The polymeric seal support forms a housing around the glass envelope and base, creating a liquid-tight seal and improving thermal insulation. Materials like fluorocarbon and silicone are chosen for their high-temperature resistance and chemical inertness. The seal support can be customized with additives, such as color, for identification or electromagnetic absorbance properties.  
• The invention includes optional potting material, such as silicone, to stabilize electrical leads and minimize air volume within the lamp assembly. This potting material enhances structural stability and prevents gas infiltration into the lamp's interior. The combination of the polymeric seal support and potting material significantly improves the lamp's durability and resistance to environmental factors.  
• The polymeric seal support provides a longer sealing surface compared to traditional O-rings, with a seal length approximately 13 times greater. This extended seal length, combined with controlled stretch and compression levels, ensures a more reliable and durable seal. The elimination of adhesives also allows for better centering of the glass envelope within the base, improving overall alignment and performance.  
• The invention reduces the risk of burns by insulating the metal base and minimizing

<summary>  
• The document describes a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) precoder for multi-user MIMO systems, focusing on reducing computational costs while maintaining system capacity. It introduces a novel method to compute the precoder matrices without requiring knowledge of the "Least Favorable Noise" covariance matrix.  
• The GDFE precoder includes an interference pre-cancellation block and a transmit filter, which are optimized to handle interference and improve system performance. The method avoids channel reduction when the input covariance matrix is rank deficient, making it suitable for practical systems.  
• The document provides detailed mathematical formulations for computing the filter matrix C, transmit filter matrix B, feedforward filter matrix F, and interference pre-cancellation matrix G. These matrices are derived using QR decomposition and other linear algebra techniques.  
• Numerical examples are included to illustrate the computation of these matrices for different scenarios, such as varying transmit power and rectangular channel matrices. These examples demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in real-world applications.  
• The GDFE precoder is designed to optimize system capacity and bit error rate, making it suitable for future 4G cellular networks. It achieves this by pre-canceling interference and ensuring efficient power allocation across user terminals.  
• The document concludes by highlighting the advantages of the proposed method, including reduced computational complexity and improved performance in multi-user MIMO systems. It also provides references to prior work and theoretical foundations supporting the proposed approach.  
</summary>

<summary>  
• The invention introduces a heat-dissipating device and its housing, focusing on an axial fan designed to increase the intake airflow rate without altering assembly conditions with other components. The fan's housing features an outward-extending sidewall to enlarge the intake airflow area, enhancing heat-dissipating efficiency while maintaining compatibility with existing systems.
